z:row.TitlePrimary: Tutankhamun's chariots: secret treasures of engineering mechanics
z:row.Keyword: ancient engineering|ancient fracture control|ancient machines|chariots|chariot design|multiaxial loading|Engineering, Mechanical|Materials Science, Multidisciplinary
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Fatigue & Fracture of Engineering Materials & Structures
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: OXFORD; 9600 GARSINGTON RD, OXFORD OX4 2DG, OXON, ENGLAND
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ Wisconsin, Dept Engn Phys, Madison, WI 53706 USA.; Sandor, BI, Univ Wisconsin, Dept Engn Phys, Madison, WI 53706 USA.; sandor@engr.wisc.edu
z:row.Abstract: The Tutankhamun-class chariot is the earliest high-performance machine, most likely developed via racing and thoughtful mechanistic modelling and testing, and made with exquisite craftsmanship. The complex suspension system of springs and dampers comprises simple elements that are useful by chance, and also some well-designed and expensive components and subassemblies for advantages in structural dynamics and ride quality. These chariots' spokes and joints have aircraft-like damage tolerance, and are more sophisticated than those of any veteran car with wooden wheels. A substantially better overall design with the ancient materials of construction is difficult to visualize even if we apply our knowledge and computerized methods. This makes the Egyptian chariot an excellent example of original and advanced design, and a formidable challenge in further engineering investigations aimed at a full understanding of the ancients' achievements.

z:row.TitlePrimary: Numerical simulation of stress intensity factors via the thermoelastic technique
z:row.Keyword: finite element analysis|j-integral|least squares method|stress intensity factors|thermoelastic stress analysis|Mechanics
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: THOUSAND OAKS; 2455 TELLER RD, THOUSAND OAKS, CA 91320
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: STRESS PHOTON INC,MADISON,WI 53716. UNIV WISCONSIN,DEPT NUCL ENGN & ENGN PHYS,MADISON,WI 53706.; Ju, SH, NATL CHENG KUNG UNIV,DEPT CIVIL ENGN,TAINAN 70101,TAIWAN.
z:row.Abstract: The purpose of this study is to investigate the accuracy of the least squares method for finding the in-plane stress intensity factors K-I and K-II using thermoelastic data from isotropic materials. To fully understand the idealized condition of K-I and K-II calculated from thermoelastic experiments, the total stress field calculated from finite element analysis is used to take the place of data obtained from real thermoelastic experiments. In the finite element analysis, the J-integral is also calculated to compare with (K-I(2) + K-II(2))/E evaluated by the least squares method. The stress fields near the crack tip are dominated by the two stress intensity factors; however, the edge effect will cause inaccuracy of the thermoelastic data near the crack tip. Furthermore, the scan area of thermoelastic experiments cannot be too small. Therefore, we suggest that three or four terms of stress function be included in the least squares method for evaluating stress intensity factors via the thermoelastic technique. In the idealized condition, the error can be smaller than 3 percent from our numerical simulations. If only the r(-1/2) term (K-I and K-II) is included in the least squares method, even in the idealized case the error can be up to 20 percent.

z:row.TitlePrimary: Life prediction of solder joints by damage and fracture mechanics
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: NEW YORK; 345 E 47TH ST, NEW YORK, NY 10017
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: UNIV WISCONSIN,DEPT NUCL ENGN & ENGN PHYS,ENGN MECH & ASTRONAUT PROGRAM,MADISON,WI 53706.; Ju, SH, NATL CHENG KUNG UNIV,DEPT CIVIL ENGN,TAINAN 70101,TAIWAN.
z:row.Abstract: Much research has been done on Surface Mount Technology (SMT) using the Finite Element Method (FEM). Little of this, however, has employed fracture mechanics and/or continuum damage mechanics. In this study, we propose two finite element approaches incorporating fracture mechanics and continuum damage mechanics to predict time-dependent and temperature-dependent fatigue life of solder joints. For fracture mechanics, the J-integral fatigue formula, da/dN = C(Delta J)(m), is used to quantify fatigue crack growth and the fatigue life of J-leaded solder joints. For continuum damage mechanics, the anisotropic creep-fatigue damage formula with partially reversible damage effects is used to find the initial crack, crack growth path, and fatigue life of solder joints. The concept of partially reversible damage is especially novel and, based on laboratory tests we have conducted, appears to be necessary for solder joints undergoing cyclic loading. Both of these methods are adequate to predict the fatigue life of solder joints. The advantage of the fracture mechanics approach is that little computer time is required The disadvantage is that assumptions must be made on the initial crack position and the crack growth path. The advantage of continuum damage mechanics is that the initial crack and its growth path are automatically evaluated with the temporary disadvantage of requiring a lot of computer time.

z:row.TitlePrimary: Creep rupture investigation of 63Sn-37Pb solder by experiments and damage mechanics
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: W CONSHOHOCKEN; 100 BARR HARBOR DR, W CONSHOHOCKEN, PA 19428-2959
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: UNIV WISCONSIN,DEPT NUCL ENGN & ENGN PHYS,MADISON,WI 53706.; Ju, SH, NATL CHUNG CHENG UNIV,DEPT CIVIL ENGN,TAINAN,TAIWAN.
z:row.Abstract: The main purpose of this paper is to investigate the crack growth path and creep rupture life of 63Sn-37Pb bulk solder experimentally by Moire analysis and theoretically using continuum damage mechanics. In conventional fracture mechanics analysis, a crack growth path is assumed a priori. Fracture parameters such as the J-integral and stress intensity factor are subsequently calculated to predict the crack growth rate and structural life. However, it is often difficult to postulate the correct crack growth path for a complex structure that is subject to complex loading. Continuum damage mechanics is an alternative method that can be used to compute structural life with the important feature that the crack growth path is computed automatically. In this paper we develop a theory for partially reversible creep-fatigue damage. A finite element procedure incorporating this damage theory is developed and used to analyze the response of bulk solder plates with holes. The displacement fields obtained by finite element analysis are compared to the fringe patterns obtained from conventional Moire experiments. Furthermore, the accuracy of the predicted crack growth paths was investigated by comparison between the maximum damage contours obtained by finite element simulation with the actual crack paths occurring in the laboratory specimens. These comparisons indicate the new continuum damage theory developed herein can adequately predict creep displacements, crack growth paths, and structural life.

z:row.TitlePrimary: Influence of Substrate Deformations on the Thermal Fatigue Life of Smt Solder Joints
z:row.Keyword: SMT SOLDER JOINTS|LIFE PREDICTION|SUBSTRATE DEFORMATIONS|PRINTED WIRING BOARDS|Materials Science, Characterization & Testing
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: W CONSHOHOCKEN; 100 BARR HARBOR DR, W CONSHOHOCKEN, PA 19428-2959
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: UNIV WISCONSIN,DEPT ENGN MECH & ASTRONAUT,MADISON,WI 53706.; ZAFRAN, JB, ADA,HAIFA,ISRAEL.
z:row.Abstract: Previously published expressions based on life data for bulk solder are used in this paper to calculate the number of thermal cycles to failure of the solder joints of leadless chip carriers attached to various substrates. The devices used by Hall in thermal chamber cycling and power cycling are chosen for analysis. The values of deformations in terms of shear strain range and total mismatch are presented and compared. The fatigue lives of the solder joints are predicted based on the deformation data, the test conditions, and the Coffin-Manson expression. Attempts are made to correct some crucial differences in previous work or to fill in for missing information. The resulting predictions are explained according to the specific models used.

z:row.TitlePrimary: Thermoelastic Determination of Individual Stress Components in Loaded Composites
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: DETROIT DIESEL CO,W DETROIT,MI 48239. UNIV WISCONSIN,DEPT ENGN MECH,MADISON,WI 53706.; FENG, Z, JILIN UNIV TECHNOL,CHANGCHUN,PEOPLES R CHINA.
z:row.Abstract: An experimental-numerical hybrid method is developed for determining the individual stresses in orthotropic composites from measured thermoelastic information. This includes evaluating the thermoelastic calibration co-efficients, effective processing of the noisy measured data, and separating the stress components at nonboundary locations. The method is illustrated experimentally by application to a uniaxially loaded fiber-reinforced composite plate containing a central circular hole.

z:row.TitlePrimary: Tutankhamun's chariots: Secret treasures of engineering mechanics
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Fatigue and Fracture of Engineering Materials and Structures
z:row.Publisher: Blackwell Publishing Ltd, Oxford, United Kingdom
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Department of Engineering Physics, University of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, United States
z:row.Abstract: The Tutankhamun-class chariot is the earliest high-performance machine, most likely developed via racing and thoughtful mechanistic modelling and testing, and made with exquisite craftsmanship. The complex suspension system of springs and dampers comprises simple elements that are useful by chance, and also some well-designed and expensive components and subassemblies for advantages in structural dynamics and ride quality. These chariots' spokes and joints have aircraft-like damage tolerance, and are more sophisticated than those of any veteran car with wooden wheels. A substantially better overall design with the ancient materials of construction is difficult to visualize even if we apply our knowledge and computerized methods. This makes the Egyptian chariot an excellent example of original and advanced design, and a formidable challenge in further engineering investigations aimed at a full understanding of the ancients' achievements.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Ancient engineering; Ancient fracture control; Chariots; Chariot design; Multiaxial loading

z:row.TitlePrimary: Corrosion fatigue modeling via differential infrared thermography
z:row.Keyword: Corrosion fatigue|Thermography (imaging)|Nondestructive examination|Stress analysis|Thermal effects|Stress corrosion cracking|Image analysis|Image quality|Mathematical models|Error analysis|Temperature measurement
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Differential infrared thermography is a method used to detect the subsurface defects in aging aircrafts, aging bridges, and total joint arthroplasty. This technique is successfully applied in stress analysis and surface crack identification by using a unique infrared camera system to detect temperature gradients as small as 0.001 K. The development of a methodology to monitor and quantify wear particles or corrosion between two surfaces or within the boundaries of a material is presented.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Differential infrared thermography; Forced diffusion thermography (FDT)

z:row.TitlePrimary: Forced diffusion thermography for nondestructive evaluation of microstructures
z:row.TitleSecondary: Proceedings of the 1997 TMS Annual Meeting, Feb 10-13 1997
z:row.Keyword: Microstructure|Thermography (temperature measurement)|Nondestructive examination|Mathematical models|Finite element method|Cracks|Crystal defects|Fluxes
z:row.Publisher: Minerals, Metals & Materials Soc (TMS), Warrendale, PA, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Forced Diffusion Thermography (FDT) has been developed recently for structural integrity assessment in large structures. This paper presents FDT to identify microscopic flaws by both finite element analysis and experimentation. The technical difficulties are the production of a microscopic width heat flux line pattern and the spatial and temperature resolution of the infrared camera. A finite element model 1 mm square and 0.3 mm deep of tin solder material with various surface crack sizes have produced a temperature difference of 1 to 4 mK across the crack. Testing of specimens with known microscopic flaws was performed using an infrared camera with a temperature resolution of 1 mK. A low power helium-neon laser provided an AC heat input area approximately 500 µm wide by several millimeters long to the specimen's surface. The results show that this method can be applied to detect flaws in small specimens of solder and similar materials.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Forced diffusion thermography (FDT)

z:row.TitlePrimary: Reversibility of creep-fatigue damage in 63Sn-37Pb solder
z:row.TitleSecondary: Proceedings of the International Intersociety Electronic Packaging Conference -INTERpack'95. Part 2 (of 2), Mar 26-30 1995
z:row.TitleTertiary: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, EEP
z:row.Keyword: Soldering alloys|Tin alloys|Lead alloys|Shear stress|Creep testing|Fatigue testing|Crack propagation|Failure (mechanical)|Fatigue of materials|Mathematical models|Continuum mechanics|Loads (forces)
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: This paper explores the reversibility of damage in 63Sn-37Pb solder using bimaterial shear experiments. We have first demonstrated the reversibility of damage due to compression, which has been qualitatively known in the general fatigue area, but has not been quantitatively investigated using modern models. The reversibility of damage in shear is not nearly so obvious, because the fracture behaviors in tension-compression and cyclic shear are usually different. In our bimaterial shear experiments, the specimen is two pieces of copper joined by a layer of 63Sn-37Pb solder with a thickness of 1 mm (0.04 in.). The applied loading is a trapezoidal wave shape with various hold times. An extensometer is used to measure the cyclic displacement between the two copper plates. The results of experiments indicate that the reversible damage effect plays an important role in the failure of solder under cyclic shear stress. This phenomenon is not considered in current isotropic or anisotropic continuum damage mechanics; therefore, it is necessary to generate a reversible-damage theory for solder materials. Incorporating this theory in the finite element method, we can better predict fatigue life and crack growth paths for a complex solder joint under complex loads.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Cyclic displacement; Creep fatigue damage; Damage reversibility; Bimaterial shear experiments; Continuum damage mechanics

z:row.TitlePrimary: Creep-fatigue damage analysis of solder joints
z:row.TitleSecondary: Symposium on Fatigue of Electronic Materials, May 17 1993
z:row.Keyword: Soldered joints|Continuum mechanics|Fatigue of materials|Creep|Mathematical models|Finite element method|Stresses|Strain|Failure analysis|Crack propagation|Anisotropy
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: An anisotropic model of continuum damage mechanics has been developed to predict the creep-fatigue life of solder joints. With the help of the finite element method, the stress, strain, and damage fields of the time-dependent and temperature-dependent solder can be obtained. The main advantages of this model include: (1) It can predict the initial crack location and time and the subsequent crack growth paths; (2) The damage analysis is almost the same as in traditional viscoelastic finite element analysis; (3) It can be applied to a complex structure with any loading; (4) It provides a full-field damage investigation of the structure. This damage theory can be used for various solder joints and also can be applied to analyze the creep-fatigue problems of other ductile and temperature-dependent materials. Extensive experiments including uniaxial creep, uniaxial fatigue, tension-torsion, Moire, and bimaterial tests were performed to validate the new model. These validations and comparisons indicate that this model can predict adequately crack growth paths and fatigue lives of solder joints.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Damage analysis; Time dependent solder; Temperature dependent solder; Isotropic; Continuum damage mechanics; Viscoelastic

z:row.TitlePrimary: Life prediction of solder joints by damage and fracture mechanics
z:row.TitleSecondary: Proceedings of the 1993 ASME Winter Annual Meeting, Nov 28-Dec 3 1993
z:row.TitleTertiary: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, EEP
z:row.Keyword: Soldered joints|Fatigue of materials|Fracture mechanics|Forecasting|Continuum mechanics|Finite element method|Integral equations|Crack propagation|Creep|Surface mount technology|Mathematical models
z:row.Publisher: Publ by ASME, New York, NY, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Much research has been done on Surface Mount Technology (SMT) using the Finite Element Method (FEM). Little of this, however, has employed fracture mechanics and/or continuum damage mechanics. In this study, we propose two finite element approaches incorporating fracture mechanics and continuum damage mechanics to predict time-dependent and temperature-dependent fatigue life of solder joints. For fracture mechanics, the J-integral fatigue formula, da/dN= C (ΔJ)m, is used to quantify fatigue crack growth and the fatigue life of J-leaded solder joints. For continuum damage mechanics, the anisotropic creep-fatigue damage formula with partially reversible damage effects is used to find the initial crack, crack growth path and fatigue life of solder joints. The concept of partially reversible damage is especially novel and, based on laboratory tests we have conducted, appears to be necessary for solder joints undergoing cyclic loading. Both of these methods are adequate to predict the fatigue life of solder joints. The advantage of the fracture mechanics approach is that little computer time is required. Its disadvantage is that assumptions must be made on the initial crack position and the crack growth path. The advantage of continuum damage mechanics is that the initial crack and its growth path are automatically evaluated, with the temporary disadvantage of requiring much computer time.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Life prediction; Damage mechanics; Fatigue life; J-integral fatigue formula; Anisotropic creep fatigue damage formula; Damage effects; Time dependent; Temperature dependent

z:row.TitlePrimary: Influence of substrate deformations on the thermal fatigue life of SMT solder joints
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Previously published expressions based on life data for bulk solder are used to calculate the number of thermal cycles to failure of the solder joints of leadless chip carriers attached to various substrates. The devices used by Hall in thermal chamber cycling and power cycling are chosen for analysis. The values of deformation in terms of shear strain range and total mismatch are presented and compared. The fatigue lives of the solder joints are predicted based on the deformation data, the test conditions, and the Coffin-Manson expression
z:row.User2: surface mount technology solder joints; substrate deformations; thermal fatigue life; thermal cycles; failure; leadless chip carriers; thermal chamber cycling; power cycling; shear strain range; Coffin-Manson expression

z:row.TitlePrimary: Advances in thermographic stress analysis and evaluation of damage in composites
z:row.TitleSecondary: 10th Conference on Composite Materials: Testing and Design, Apr 24-25 1990
z:row.Keyword: Composite Materials -- Fiber Reinforcement|Composite Materials - Stresses|Composite Materials - Structural Analysis|Thermography - Applications|Thermoelasticity
z:row.Publisher: Publ by ASTM, Philadelphia, PA, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Development of the thermographic stress analysis (TSA) method and the stress pattern analysis by thermal emission (SPATE) method for stress analysis and evaluation of damage in fiber-reinforced composites during the past five years is reviewed, and some new results are presented. The fundamental factors affecting the TSA signals, calibration methods, stress analysis, stress (strain) separation, and methods of qualitative and quantitative evaluation of damage are discussed. Reasonable future research topics are outlined.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Damage Evaluation; Thermographic Stress Analysis; Stress Pattern Analysis

z:row.TitlePrimary: Damage evaluation in composite materials using thermographic stress analysis
z:row.TitleSecondary: Advances in Fatigue Lifetime Predictive Techniques, Apr 24 1990
z:row.Publisher: Publ by ASTM, Philadelphia, PA, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Damage in composite materials initiates and propagates randomly at many sites, which makes both the monitoring and evaluation of its local and global effects difficult. The recently developed thermographic stress analysis method (TSA) provides unique opportunities for full-field damage investigation. To make quantitative analysis possible, a thermoelasticity theory for damage in anisotropic materials was developed. The TSA method associated with this theory opens new doors in investigating the microstructure-mechanics connection of multiphase materials, and in establishing quantitative prediction capabilities of microscopic behaviors and service lives. Experiments have been performed to measure the damage parameter D, the normalized effective mass density ρc/ρ, and the effective modulus Ev in glass/epoxy [$0/90/0/90/0]s and [0/90]s laminates by the TSA method. Good correlations between the effective moduli of the laminates measured by the TSA method and by an extensometer are found. A relationship between the effective modulus Ev, the undamaged material's modulus E, the number of damaging cyclic loads N, and the peak nominal stress σmax is used to describe the progressive reduction of the modulus. In light of the new thermoelasticity theory for damage, the normalized effective mass density is determined quite easily by the TSA method in comparison with conventional experimental techniques.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Damage Evaluation; Thermographic Stress Analysis

z:row.TitlePrimary: Straddle-board modeling of SMT joint behaviors
z:row.TitleSecondary: 1990 Proceedings. 40th Electronic Components and Technology Conference (Cat. No.90CH2893-6), 20-23 May 1990
z:row.TitleTertiary: 1990 Proceedings. 40th Electronic Components and Technology Conference (Cat. No.90CH2893-6)
z:row.Keyword: deformation|fatigue|modelling|printed circuits|soldering|surface mount technology|thermal expansion|thermal stress cracking
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Eng. Math., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Straddle-board specimens consisting of a chip carrier connected by J-leads to a printed wiring board were tested isothermally at room temperature. Thermal expansions were simulated by controlling the deflection of the bisectioned printed wiring board. Initial results are presented from using the straddle-board configuration for material response and fatigue life analysis of actual surface-mounted joints. The leads were subjected to two typical extreme modes of deformation, longitudinal and transverse deflections, to determine the behaviors and damage in each case. It was found that the transverse component of the lead deflection, which increases in magnitude toward the corner of the chip carrier, is more damaging than the longitudinal component, which does not vary from lead to lead. The fatigue data, plotted as percent load drop versus cycles, follows a linear pattern during the initial stages of damage. The effects of stress relaxation on the rate of loading show a logarithmic correlation with deflection
z:row.User2: PWB mounted SMD; loading rate; isothermal testing; SMT joint behaviors; chip carrier; J-leads; printed wiring board; room temperature; straddle-board configuration; material response; fatigue life analysis; surface-mounted joints; deformation; transverse deflections; lead deflection; longitudinal component; stress relaxation

z:row.TitlePrimary: Thermoelasticity theory for damage in anisotropic materials
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Fatigue and Fracture of Engineering Materials & Structures
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: A thermoelasticity theory for damage in anisotropic materials is developed. This theory can be applied to evaluate the damage parameter D, the normalized effective mess density ρe/ρ, and the effective modulus Ee quantitatively in some metals and composites by incorporating the thermographic stress analysis method (TSA; also, SPATE method). The effective moduli due to fatigue damage and static loads in a glass fiber/epoxy laminate obtained by the TSA method are compared with the values measured by an extensometer. The correlation between the measurements using the two methods is very good.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Thermoelasticity Theory; Damage Assessment

z:row.TitlePrimary: Thermographic stress analysis of composite materials
z:row.Keyword: Composite Materials -- Stresses|Stresses - Thermal|Imaging Techniques|Heat Transfer
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Several critical aspects of stress measurements in composite materials by thermographic stress analysis (TSA; also SPATE method) have been investigated. The emphasis is on the observed effects of thermal-expansion coefficients with positive and negative signs, thickness of surface coating, and absolute temperature increases in the material due to cyclic loading. Heat transfer and mean stress effects are also discussed.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved

z:row.TitlePrimary: Differential infrared thermography: a correlation with stress and strain in cortical bone
z:row.TitleTertiary: AMD (Symposia Series) (American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Applied Mechanics Division)
z:row.Publisher: Publ by American Soc of Mechanical Engineers (ASME), New York, NY, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Differential infrared thermography represents the emergence of a new experimental technique for biomechanical application. It provides a means of analysis which is based on an unexploited physical phenomenon, thus offering an entirely new range of research opportunities. This method also provides an effective full-field alternative to current experimental strain analysis techniques. Thermographical analysis showed consistent results for an orthotropic material such as bone. By establishing the feasibility of this particular technique with a controlled test specimen, material parameters can be developed lending to the analysis of a more complex structure such as an entire femur. In conclusion, this study has shown that differential infrared thermography is a useful technique for qualitative and quantitative biomechanical applications.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Bovine Femur; Spate Method; Differential Infrared Thermography; Bone Remodeling; Thermographic Strain Analysis; Isotropic Thermoelastic Media

z:row.TitlePrimary: Low-cycle fatigue analysis of notched members
z:row.Keyword: Aluminum and Alloys -- Fatigue|Metals Testing--Crack Propagation|Materials Testing--Notched Bar|Fracture Mechanics--Calculations|Aluminum Sheet--Testing
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Low-cycle fatigue crack initiation and propagation lives of notched members are investigated. The material tested was 7075-T651 aluminum sheet. Fatigue crack initiation and propagation tests were conducted on notched plate specimens of different notch radii and stress ratios. Crack initiation life, crack propagation life, and total fatigue life are compared with the calculations. There are good correlations between the test results and the calculations.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Low-Cycle Fatigue; Fatigue Crack Initiation; Notched Plate Specimens; Stress Intensity Factor; Strain Energy Density; Aluminum Alloy 7075-T651

z:row.TitlePrimary: Thermographic analysis of stress concentrations in a composite
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: This paper examines the stress concentrations in the knit yarn/fiber intersections in a unidirectional carbon/epoxy composite. Stress-concentration factors for four different knit yarn spacings are determined by thermographic stress analysis (TSA). This method is also known in the technical community by several other names. For example the SPATE method (referring to commercially available infrared equipment), and thermoelastic stress analysis. The latter term is not sufficiently descriptive since it is also used to describe purely analytical studies of thermal-stress problems of different phenomenology. Because of these and other technical considerations, TSA is the most accurate and specific terminology for the method at hand. The two-parameter Weibull distribution function has been applied to analyze the experimental results, and the correlation between the measured values and the distribution is shown to be very good.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Thermographic Analysis; Stress Concentrations

z:row.TitlePrimary: Room temperature creep of 60/40 tin-lead solder joints
z:row.TitleSecondary: Preprint - American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Nov 27-Dec 2 1988
z:row.Publisher: Publ by American Soc of Mechanical Engineers (ASME), New York, NY, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The room temperature creep of 60/40 tin-lead solder joints in shear was investigated using both dead-weight creep and stress relaxation tests. The results show that the steady-state creep rate can be related to the stress via a simple power law relationship. A compilation of creep data from other sources is presented, and possible explanations for observed discrepancies are given.

z:row.TitlePrimary: NONDESTRUCTIVE TESTING USING DIFFERENTIAL INFRARED THERMOGRAPHY
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Differential IR thermography is a new but reasonably reliable technique for nondestructive testing and evaluation of a wide range of materials. The examples in this paper represent the tip of the iceberg regarding what has already been done in this area in a few laboratories, and they imply further important developments. It is of particular interest that the method allows not only qualitative work such as finding flaws, but also quantitative analysis of the effects of flaws on strength and durability of machine and structural components.

z:row.TitlePrimary: THERMOELASTIC ANALYSIS OF THE PROXIMAL CANINE FEMUR
z:row.TitleSecondary: 1987 Advances in Bioengineering. Presented at the Winter Annual Meeting of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers.
z:row.Keyword: BIOLOGICAL MATERIALS -- Thermoelasticity|BIOMECHANICS - Cadaveric Experiments|INFRARED IMAGING - Medical Applications|THERMOGRAPHY - Medical Applications|INFRARED DEVICES - Medical Applications
z:row.Publisher: ASME (DE v 12), New York, NY, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: A preliminary study has been performed to investigate the potential of infrared thermography in biomechanical applications of experimental stress analysis. The stress patterns of six mongrel adult dog femurs were evaluated by the SPATE method (Stress Pattern Analysis by Thermal Emission) developed by Ometron, Inc. An infrared radiographic scan was used to measure temperature changes caused by elastic deformation of a specimen during cyclic loading.

z:row.TitlePrimary: A hyperbolic relationship for stress vs. life [fatigue]
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Fatigue of Engineering Materials and Structures
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Engng. Mech., Univ. of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: A hyperbolic relationship for alternating stress vs. fatigue life has been proposed. This relationship approaches Basquin's equation for long lives. It is in agreement with published stress-life data for 2024 and 7075 aluminum, and Ti-8Al-1Mo-1V. Two different approaches have been considered to account for mean stress effects and one is argued to be better than the other. A hyperbolic fatigue strength exponent is a linear function of the mean stress in the first one and this relationship well represents the mean stress fatigue data of 7075 aluminum. Like the Basquin equation, a fatigue limit is not accounted for in the hyperbolic relationship, nor is one observed in the three materials considered. The knee in the stress-life data of 7075 aluminum at about 106 reversals to failure appears to be a consequence of constant amplitude testing; it is not observed in the stress-life data from variable amplitude tests. Therefore, the proposed hyperbolic relationships for stress vs. life apply for fatigue lives up to 109 reversals, and probably even further. At long lives, the hyperbolic relationship is conservative for constant amplitude loading, and it is more realistic for variable amplitude loading
z:row.User2: 2024 Al alloy; Ti-Al-Mo-V; 7075 Al alloy; hyperbolic relationship; fatigue life; fatigue strength; Basquin equation; fatigue limit; stress-life data; constant amplitude testing; variable amplitude loading

z:row.TitlePrimary: LOCALISED CYCLIC CREEP IN NOTCHED STEEL PLATES
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Res Mechanica: International Journal of Structural Mechanics and Materials Science
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wis, Madison
z:row.Abstract: Results from experiments performed on SAE 1043 steel plates show that cyclic creep may occur in a localized region at a notch root, even if the whole member does not exhibit permanent uniaxial deformation. Two different notch geometries were studied. The more sharply notched specimens had a higher rate and a larger zone of cyclic creep. This zone size was about twice as large as the plastic zone size by the first few percent of the life. Four different values for average mean stress were used. Both tensile and compressive cyclic creep were observed. Greater mean stresses caused higher rates and larger zones of cyclic creep. Values for cyclic creep of 1000 microstrain by the first few percent of the life were fairly common. Stress relieving did not appear to cause a significant difference in the cyclic creep rate.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: CYCLIC CREEP

z:row.TitlePrimary: ISOLATION OF THE TIME-DEPENDENT STRAIN COMPONENT USING FATIGUE DAMAGE
z:row.Keyword: METALS TESTING|STRAIN - Analysis|METALS AND ALLOYS - Creep|MATERIALS - Crack Propagation|ALUMINUM AND ALLOYS
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wis, Madison, USA
z:row.Abstract: The paper presents the results of an attempt to separate the time-dependent component of strain from the elastic, plastic, and cyclic-creep components of strain in a notched fatigue specimen. The strain is estimated from the amount of damage done to a fatigue specimen in the form of the extension of a crack. This method is demonstrated in room-temperature tests on a medium-strength aluminum, but is applicable to higher or lower temperatures and/or different materials. A second aim of this report is to compare three different methods for measuring the crack length. These are: optical microscopic measurement, crack propagation gauges produced by Micro-Measurements, and the Fractomat crack measurement system. Refs.

z:row.Abstract: Presents the results of an attempt to separate the time-dependent component of strain from the elastic plastic, and cyclic-creep components of strain in a notched fatigue specimen. The strain is estimated from the amount of damage done to a fatigue specimen in the form of the extension of a crack. This method is demonstrated in room-temperature tests on a medium-strength aluminium, but is applicable to higher or lower temperatures and/or different materials. Three different methods for measuring the crack length are compared. These are: optical microscopic measurement, crack propagation gauges and the Fractomat crack measurement system

z:row.TitlePrimary: Stress analysis from temperature data
z:row.Keyword: carbon steel|elastic deformation|plastic deformation|stress analysis|temperature measurement
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Engng. Mech. Dept., Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: A measurement system for monitoring temperature change during mechanical deformation is described. The system is based on thermocouples welded directly to the specimen and is capable of distinguishing temperatures smaller than 0.1°C with a response time less than 0.01 s. An equation to relate temperature change to mechanical variables is stated and experimentally verified. The scalar quantity temperature can be used in stress analysis to determine other scalar quantities related to stress or both stress and plastic strain. Three methods are proposed for analyzing temperature data. The methods are discussed in terms of the basic equation and are experimentally verified. A key element in these methods is the use of rapid loading and rapid data collection that results in data not appreciably altered by heat conduction. Collectively these methods can be used to detect plastic strains as small as 0.0003 m/m in mild steel, to determine magnitudes of specific plastic work, and to determine pressure for elastic deformation. The authors discuss the theoretical and experimental foundations for techniques potentially useful to the study of notched members
z:row.User2: temperature data; measurement system; monitoring temperature change; mechanical deformation; thermocouples; mechanical variables; scalar quantity temperature; stress analysis; plastic strain; rapid loading; rapid data collection; heat conduction; mild steel; specific plastic work; elastic deformation; notched members

z:row.TitlePrimary: High cycle fatigue crack propagation rates in copper
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ. Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The crack propagation rate was studied on axially loaded specimens of oxygen-free, high conductivity copper tested in the high cycle life region. Fatigue tests were conducted under load control without a mean load. The variables of the test conditions were the engineering stress range, the average grain size, and the atmosphere (air and argon gas). The crack propagation rate during the first 80 percent of the life was determined by using an electropolishing technique. The rate was also measured after final failure of each specimen from the distances of the striations on the fracture surface observed through a scanning electron microscope. The crack propagation rate depended upon the test conditions as well as on the prior stress cycling. The crack propagation was divided into two main stages: the crack nucleation and microcrack development stage, and the crack propagation or macrocrack development stage
z:row.User2: high cycle fatigue crack propagation rates; axially loaded specimens; fatigue tests; crack nucleation; microcrack development stage; crack propagation; macrocrack development stage; Cu

z:row.TitlePrimary: Fatigue behavior of copper with intermediate surface layer removal
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ. Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The effect of single and periodic intermediate surface layer removal on the fatigue behavior of oxygen-free, high-conductivity copper was studied in the life range of 105 to 2×106 cycles. The fatigue tests were conducted at room temperature, in tension-compression, under load control, and without mean load. The surface layer removal was accomplished by electropolishing. The variables of the test conditions were the engineering stress range, the average grain size, and the atmosphere (air and argon gas)
z:row.User2: fatigue; intermediate surface layer removal; room temperature; electropolishing; engineering stress range; average grain size; precycling; average plastic strain; damage retardation; atmosphere dependence; Cu; tension compression testing; load control test; without mean load test

z:row.TitlePrimary: The extension of low cycle fatigue concepts
z:row.TitleSecondary: Proceedings of the 4th Conference on Dimensioning and Strength Calculations, Oct. 1971
z:row.TitleTertiary: Proceedings of the 4th Conference on Dimensioning and Strength Calculations
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ. Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The strengthening mechanism provided by cyclic strain aging in low carbon steel is used to emphasize the significance of cyclic plasticity in fatigue damage accumulation. Cyclic plastic strains are considered important at all ranges of fatigue lives, not only in low cycle fatigue. Strain aging techniques show that a careful analysis of cyclic plastic strains offers the best physical basis to account for the accumulation of fatigue damage under complex loading or temperature conditions. The opportunities and limitations of the analytical method are discussed in terms of the required material constants and their availability from relatively simple mechanical tests. The most urgent problems in the area of cyclic plasticity are presented with respect to the damage analysis method
z:row.User2: low cycle fatigue concepts; strengthening mechanism; low carbon steel; cyclic plasticity; fatigue damage accumulation; cyclic strain aging

z:row.TitlePrimary: The relaxation of mean stresses at elevated temperatures
z:row.TitleSecondary: Proceedings of the 4th Conference on Dimensioning and Strength Calculations, Oct. 1971
z:row.TitleTertiary: Proceedings of the 4th Conference on Dimensioning and Strength Calculations
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ. Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Cyclic creep and the relaxation of mean stresses are discussed with respect to cyclic plasticity, loading control, material homogeneity, and cycle dependent stress-strain response. Relaxation processes are important in life estimates for service at any temperature because they may affect beneficial (compressive) or harmful (tensile) residual stresses. Guidelines are presented and relatively simple tests at elevated temperatures are recommended to designers who must assess the potential significance of mean stresses under particular loading and environmental conditions
z:row.User2: relaxation of mean stresses; elevated temperatures; cyclic creep; cyclic plasticity; loading control; material homogeneity; life estimates; fatigue damage accumulation; cycle dependent stress/strain response

z:row.TitlePrimary: The resistivity of MgO powder at elevated temperatures
z:row.Keyword: dielectric materials|electrical conductivity of solids|insulating materials|magnesium compounds|powders
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ. Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: A simple apparatus is described for the measurement of resistivity of electric powders at elevated temperatures. MgO powder is tested in the range of temperatures from room temperature to 500°C. A large decrease of resistivity is observed at about 50°C, which is in contrast to a previously reported decrease of resistivity in single crystals of MgO at much lower temperatures. The iron content in the samples of typical purity is sufficient to cause a significant lowering of the activation energy for conduction in MgO, but it is not clear why the increased conduction occurs in a narrow range of temperatures
z:row.User2: resistivity; MgO powder; elevated temperatures; activation energy
